See, the reason this happens is because of something I call the âTraffic Cliff.â

The âTraffic Cliffâ is the reason why Agora Financial (a two billion dollar per year direct response company) is so successful. Itâs the reason why one of my best friends has had his supplement company for ten years when most people fail after two.

The âTraffic Cliff â is the magical place you arrive at when you can outspend your competitors. Itâs the exponential growth curve.

If everyone else can only spend $2 per subscriber, but you can spend $2.50 youâre not gonna get 25% more subscribers than them. Youâll get 2x or 5x the subscribers because youâve just hit the cliff where they canât spend any more money... but you can.

Agora knows their numbers. They know they can spend more than anyone else. Thatâs why they did over $2 billion last year and most people are struggling to break 7 or 8 figures. Or scale from $20 million to $30 or $40 million...or to 9 figures. (Obviously there are other reasons, but this is the basis for their success.)

Agora combines the short term with the long term. Thatâs my specialty. Thatâs what I want to help you with.

Rule #7: Learn how to combine short term cash flow with long-term recurring (or at least predictable) revenue.

Thatâs why I want to tell you the rest of the story about my DirecTV days.

I ultimately learned my superpower while I was selling TV subscriptions face to face.

Remember when I said the word âinstallâ was the most important word when I had that job?

Well, itâs because soooo many people focus on the front end sale. But they rarely talk about refunds, chargebacks, and lifetime value.

When I was selling DirecTV I started making one sale a day by the second week. There was one other guy doing more than that...but I was actually making more money than him because of the âinstall.â

I want to walk you through my sales process that took me to the best performing salesman in just 2 weeks.

See, when week 2 rolled around I was able to go to my own store and sell by myself. (This meant I didnât have Timbo Slice to rely on anymore.)

I switched from Samâs Club to Best Buy.

Most guys didnât want Best Buy because it was a low traffic store. Less people go to Best Buy than Samâs Club or Walmart by a BIG multiple. But this suited me WAYYY better.

Why?

Because it allowed me to develop a relationship with my potential buyers BEFORE I sold them anything.

Mini-lesson: One of the most important selling factors in the history of selling or factors is called Know, Like, Trust. When people know you, like you, and TRUST you, theyâre WAY more likely to buy from you.
 
The more you focus on the relationship BEFORE you sell, the more youâll sell. Which is something youâll see in action when I tell you the Old Man story.

My strategy was pretty simple. I had a table to sell from, but I would stray from the table and meet customers wherever they were in the store.

Mini-lesson: Do NOT rely on people to come to you. You must meet them where they are. This has multiple meanings and layers.
 
You have to meet them where they are physically. Where do your buyers hang out? What websites? What social media platforms? What stores do they go to? Which aisle in the store?
 
First off, you can have the best pitch on planet earth, but if youâre posting ads on Myspace you arenât gonna make much money. If your buyers hang out primarily on Facebook but all you do is try to find them on LinkedIn youâre gonna struggle.


IMPORTANT
Second, you have to meet your prospect where they are emotionally and mentally. Where are they in the sales cycle? Are they aware of their problem? Aware of a solution? Aware of your solution? Do they already know you or what youâre selling?

The single most important question you can ask before writing any copy, making any pitch, or selling ANYTHING is this:

Where are they NOW?

Find out where they are physically, mentally, and emotionally and you can tailor your pitch to that place. Thatâs the difference between good and great...

...how good are you at entering the conversation thatâs already going on in their head?

***Super Tangent Time: Iâve spent most of my twenties becoming one of the best copywriters in the world. (Not just my personal opinion, I promise.)

I had no idea how that would translate to stand up comedy, but it turns out the principles are pretty similar in certain aspects.

IMPORTANT
See, the first few lines of your copy or sales pitch are the most important. (Which is something youâll see in the next chapter.)

Itâs the same thing in stand up.

The second you walk on stage the audience is forming an opinion about you. They are judging you. Theyâre seeing you through the lens of all their past prejudices.

This does NOT make them bad people. It makes them humans. Weâre constantly scanning our environment and making judgments so that we can SURVIVE.

IMPORTANT
Thatâs why people tend to trust people who look like them more than people who donât. For example, a 28 year old white dude with a beard is probably more likely to buy from me than a 71 year old Latina woman.
 
Not because sheâs racist or heâs racist, but because itâs SAFE and FAMILIAR.


ULTRA IMPORTANT
When it comes to stand up it follows the same rules. People are gonna judge you right away.

Most chubby guys would look at me and think âI wouldnât mind looking like him.â But I look at chubby guys and think âMan, I want that comedy bod.â
 
See, Iâm aware that most people (especially the dudes) wonât like me at first glance when I get on a comedy stage. I donât look like most comedians. So I HAVE to acknowledge that or they wonât buy into anything Iâm saying...even if they think itâs funny.

This ALWAYS gets a laugh (even though I donât personally think itâs that funny) because itâs what people are thinking. Their exact thoughts are âthis guy is Australian.â So when I say what theyâre thinking, they laugh.
 
Or theyâre thinking âWhere the hell is this guy from?
 
If I donât acknowledge what they're thinking, theyâll spend the rest of my set just thinking about my accent instead of listening to my jokes and stories.

When someone lands on your sales page or picks up the phone or whatever it is...you have to think âWhatâs the conversation going on in their head?â And then start there.

If you understand this one single thing, and APPLY it, you will be better than 95% of sales people on the planet.

End of tangent.***

Back to Best Buy...

I met people in the store WHERE they were. If they were checking out DVDs Iâd approach them ask âis there anything I can help you with?â Or Iâd comment on what theyâre looking at if I had something to say about it.

Iâd start with helping THEM. Because itâs not about me or my product...yet.

Iâd start a conversation and see where it went. Then, when the time felt right, Iâd ask about their TV provider. Sometimes they already had DirecTV and Iâd have nothing to sell them. No biggie.

If they didnât have DirecTV then Iâd start to talk to them about it and get them to move back to the table with me.

Mini-lesson: Thereâs an old (slightly creepy) thing that guys used to teach in the dating world. If you can get a girl to move locations with you it creates a deeper bond. It creates something called âtime-distortion.â When you go multiple places with someone it feels like youâve known them longer than you actually have.

Iâve even used this in sales videos. I did this a ton when I was selling water filters. I would start out in the middle of the office and then take them into the warehouse. Then Iâd switch to being outside, or in a kitchen.
 
The different locations create time distortion and increase trust and likability. Try it out.

Once I got them back to the table Iâd go through my standard âdo the mathâ pitch. At this point theyâd either buy...or hit me with their objections.

And hereâs where I REALLY excelled.

Mini-lesson: I learned this on a call with legendary copywriter David Deutsch. The difference between A level copywriters (the best in the world) and everyone else, tends to come down to one thing. They see and deal with objections in ADVANCE. That means they know what objections will arise before they even arise, then deal with them.

Itâs a subtle difference, but itâs the difference between a sales letter that doesnât work...and one that makes a million bucks a month.

IMPORTANT
Most sales people meet every objection with a logical counterpoint designed to further sell their product, and make their product perfect. Not me.
 
I would do that when it made sense. But I would also highlight the weaknesses of DirecTV.
 
You canât have the âperfectâ product.
 
The more âperfectâ you try to make your product appear, the less likely they are to believe you.
 
If there are flaws in your product, talk about them. But talk about them in a way that doesnât unsell your product.

Hereâs one of the best examples of that Iâve ever seen. This is for a Special Forces Hiking Boot. I know itâs a good sales pitch because I bought them. Hereâs part of the ad:

âProudly NOT Waterproof â
âYour feet need to breathe, especially while moving. Waterproof boots act as a microwave for your feet after theyâre shrink wrapped in plastic - so your feet sweat more and the waterproof boots trap it in. If rainwater, river water, or water from an alley puddle get in from the top, thereâs nowhere for it to go.

 
This will not work out well for you - youâll get pruned skin and eventually blisters that will form and then rip off, exposing raw, red skin - itâs everything bad you donât want. See what they did there?

They took one of the biggest objections and turned it into a selling point. They didnât hide it. They didnât run from the objection.

In fact, that single point is one of the reasons I bought the product. I had a pair of boots before that got wet and the water sloshed around in them for the rest of the day since it was raining. It was terrible. Now I know that wonât happen with these boots.

Do not try to be or appear perfect in your pitch or your product.

Thereâs a reason for this: Connection happens around the rough edges.

Humans are flawed. Thatâs what makes us human. People want to connect with humans, not perfect robots. Show. the rough edges. Highlight them. Show them why theyâre beautiful.

Wanna know what happens when you do this right? (Cue the Old Man Story.)

One day at Best Buy an elderly man and I started a conversation. He was in his late seventies. He was kind and gentle. He didnât care about technology, but he did like watching TV. He was perfectly happy with his current solution.
 
But once we got to talking he decided he was open to a new solution. He decided to buy from me.

I laughed and reassured him that I wouldnât be selling it to him if I didnât think it was the best option for him.

I never forgot that old man because it helped reinforce something extremely important to me.

DO NOT SELL ANYTHING YOU DONâT BELIEVE IN. And donât sell it to people who donât want it or need it.

Hereâs a cheesy line Iâve been saying lately:

âIâve stepped over a lot of dollar bills to pick up pennies in my career. But now those pennies have turned into 10, 20, and 100 dollar bills.â

Short term profit is never worth long-term loss. (Plus, if you make money in a way that you donât feel good about, youâll end up wasting the money anyways because you wonât feel like you deserve it.)

It can take minutes, hours, days, months, or years to build trust... but it only takes one second to lose it forever.

Which leads to one of the key factors for going from Good to Great:

Your Intention.

People make decisions based on how they FEEL. Thatâs why I focus so much on Feelings in Advance.

Part of the buying feeling comes down to your INTENTION. If your intention is pure, you can be average salesman but still make a ton of sales. If your intention is coming from the wrong place, you can make sales in the short term but youâll always lose in the end. (Look at the Fyre Festival guy.)


I donât say this in a way that is âwoo-woo.â Intentions have a tangible FEEL to them. That feeling affects your sales.

Mini-lesson: When I used to teach guys about dating, I had one lesson Iâd repeat over and over.
 
Women donât want to be treated as an object that youâre just trying to have sex with. If you go out with the intention of âI just wanna sleep with chicksâ youâre gonna have a real hard time. Or maybe youâll trick some women into believing you for a night or two. FACE PALM.

This bothered me more than just about anything else.

NO. They completely missed the point.

The intention is to get to know the woman and then decide if you even want to sleep with her. Or if you want to continue to get to know her. Or, you can be straight up and make your intentions to sleep with her clear.

But women are WAY better than men at reading intentions. And thatâs the beauty of intentions...you cannot fake intentions. Theyâre either pure or theyâre not.

Now, letâs be clear about something. Iâm not saying good intentions will make you a great salesman. There are plenty of broke people with great intentions.

Thatâs just my opinion, but I think itâs a good one.

Now hereâs why I told you all this before I actually explained the word âinstall.â

See, there was one guy in the office who got more sales than me. He got ten and I got seven that week. But only five of his buyers actually installed DirecTV. All seven of mine installed.

Why does that matter? Cuz we only got paid on an âinstall.â

The sales were just a vanity metric. They meant high fives at the office, but they didnât mean cash in your pocket.

Mini-lesson: Btw, this mindset is RAMPANT at masterminds when people talk about revenue. âWeâre doing so much revenue bro. Hey look how big my revenue is. My revenue is bigger than yours bro.â

Iâd love to say no one cares. But seemingly everyone cares! The reality is it doesnât mean much. You canât take revenue to the bank. (Well you can but itâs probably not gonna end well.) You can take profit to the bank.

The focus on vanity metrics like video views (Iâve been guilty of this), subscribers, or revenue can be dangerous. Focus on the numbers that matter. Not the numbers that you think look cool.

I sold in a way that was congruent with me as a person. That was congruent with the buyer. And that delivered on the promises I made.

I didnât deal with âbuyerâs remorseâ because I didnât sell in a way that would create remorse. And by week 3 I was making more sales AND installs than everyone else.

At DirecTV I didnât have anything else I could sell these folks.

But with my online business the first sale is just the beginning. I just want to break even in acquiring my customers because I know the real money is my email list and follow up.

Thatâs why I focus not just on selling, but on CONSUMPTION. I want people to succeed with my products (not just cuz Iâm a really good human being) because if they succeed with the first product, theyâre gonna buy a bunch of my other stuff too.

I focus on not just finding buyers, but the RIGHT buyers.

Not only does that make you more money in the long- term, but it creates a WAY more enjoyable business. Shitty customers = shitty business.

Great customers = Great business.

Final note: I quit the DirecTV job after four weeks. I was making good money for my age and I was the top salesman... but it was a massive time commitment.

I was working eight hours per day on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday. Saturdays and Sundays we worked ten hours. Wednesdays were the only day off. On top of that I was driving for over two hours per day. Thatâs over sixty hours per week.

I wanted to make a living, but I also wanted to have a life. Plus, I had already learned just about everything I could from that type of selling environment.

After four weeks I had had enough. I decided to coach tennis where I was making $70 to $100 an hour. That way I could coach for ten to fifteen hours per week and spend the rest of my time getting good at copywriting.


RULE #8:
THE FIRST LINE IS MOST IMPORTANT

-The One Sentence That Can Make or Break Any Sales Message-


I have a client whoâs been making it rain online since I was in high school.
 
Tim Ferriss interviewed him a few years ago about how to make a million a month from info products.
 
Heâs probably run more split tests than Iâve had hot meals.
 
I was working on one of their long-running sales letters and I said âI donât like that line. Iâd get rid of it.â
 
They got rid of it. And guess what...22% lift.
 
From ONE LINE.

That actually blew my mind a bit. I mean seriously, how could one line increase conversions by that much?

Well, Iâve actually deconstructed it and figured it out.

Itâs a really small...yet MASSIVE mistake that a ton of people make in their sales process.

And I have to come clean and say I made this mistake in almost every video I made until about a year ago.

I donât even want to think about how much money that mistake cost me.

Good news is I donât have to make it anymore since Iâm aware of it.

Plus, I can go through my own funnels and clientâs funnels and get a quick lift just by changing this line.

So which line is it?

Itâs the first line.

Now, that may seem obvious to you...and it may not.

But the first line of anything you ever write or record can dictate whether or not it will work and how well it will work.

Rule #8: The first line of any sales message is the most important. The first thing you say will dictate everything else that happens.

So letâs start at the beginning.
What was this line that we removed for a 22% lift?

It was along the lines of:

âMy name is Mike and Iâve been a Certified Nutrition Specialist and Certified Personal Trainer for 15 years.â

All we did is take that line out.

Once we tested that and got the 22% lift, we tested a new lead and got another 20% lift.

The new beginning was:

âHave you ever heard of your âPersonal Fat Threshold?â
 
You probably havenât. Itâs not something your doctor will tell you about...because most doctors donât even know what it is...â

ULTRA IMPORTANT
Hereâs where people make the mistake.
 
The first iteration is what I call âweâ copy.

Itâs all about who I (or we for a company) am FIRST. Then you get into why it matters to them (the prospect).
 
This is a mistake.
 
You want to start out with something that matters to them.

I personally like to start with questions for some of my sales letters.

For my Double Your Sales Challenge the first line was:

âWhat would it be worth to you to double your sales on just ONE of your funnels?
 
Or one of your clientâs funnels?â

That second line is key as well. Because it immediately opens up a whole new audience of freelancers, copywriters, agencies, and consultants.

Look, I donât edit a lot. Thatâs no secret to people who know me.

But if thereâs one thing Iâll spend my time on, itâs the FIRST line.

Hereâs the rule of thumb for what to focus on for your first line:

âThe purpose of the first line is to get them to read the second line. The purpose of the second line is to get them to read the third line. The purpose of the third line...you get it.â (I didnât come up with this. I think I first heard it from Joe Sugarman.)

ULTRA IMPORTANT
So if youâre ever wondering what to write for the first line, just ask yourself a simple question:
 
âDoes this first line make it almost impossible for someone to leave the page?â
 
Here are some examples of first lines that Iâve written that have worked well:

âWhen I was 15 years old, 5 men stole my freedom.â
 
âTime for a new twist on an old story youâve probably already heard.â
 
âTime for a story you probably wonât read.â
 
âJoe didnât know his marriage was going to end that night.â

And my personal favorite...

âJohn didnât know he was gonna die that night.â

Each of those is dripping with enough curiosity that you feel compelled to keep reading (or watching if itâs a video).

Youâll probably notice a pattern here too.

When I find something that works, I turn it into a template. (Then I take it one step further and sell my templates. You can see how I do that at persuasionhitman.com/templates)

You should do the same.

Go look at sales pages or video sales letters or ads in different markets and see what type of first line they use. Then adapt it to your market. You donât have to be super creative for this to work. Just donât straight up steal other peopleâs stuff. Thatâs wrong and dumb.

Thatâs why I like to go to OTHER markets and see what theyâre doing. So many people find out whatâs working in their market and rip it off. Stop. Doing. That.

Ok, so hereâs a little homework for you...

ULTRA IMPORTANT
Look at one of your funnels, ads, landers, sales calls etc.... and look at the first line or first thing you say.
 
Does it feel like you CANâT NOT keep reading?
If not, then test something new. (Or do this for a client.)
 
Donât make the mistake of opening with a sentence about your credentials or who you are.
 
NO ONE CARES YET.
 
I used to open every video with âIâm Ian from FIXT Water.â
 
What. A. Waste.
 
Nobody cared. I shouldâve waited to introduce myself until AFTER I had made it about THEM.
 
The only time I open with âmy nameâ now is if Iâm doing a parody video.

If Iâm Canât Gardone or Lie Topez or Very Grinderchuck then I want to make that crystal clear when I start the video. It sets the tone and stage for everything I say afterwards.

ULTRA IMPORTANT
So unless youâre doing parodies... donât open with your name or credentials.
 
Open with something thatâs dripping with curiosity.

Mini-lesson: If youâre ever stuck on what to use as a first line, try to start with something that opens a loop. That means something that can only be answered or elaborated on by reading or watching more. You can always start with something outrageous and tone it down later. The more intense and curiosity driven, the better.






RULE #9:
USE THE SAME LANGUAGE YOUR PROSPECTS USE

-My Not-So-Secret Sales Weapon-


If thereâs only one lever that can legitimately double your sales or conversions itâs this...

Get to know your customer better than they know themselves.

Iâm sure youâve heard that before...but I want to give you the easiest way to do that.

Thereâs one way to do that thatâs more effective than anything else Iâve ever used.

Best of all itâs free! It just takes some time on your end. (You could technically outsource it...but Iâd recommend you do it yourself in the beginning...no matter how much your time is worth.)

What is it?

GET ON THE PHONE.

I do this with both buyers and not-yet buyers.

When I get on the phone with potential customers itâs for two reasons:

  • To help get people off the fence. I basically end up getting paid to do research. Itâs a win-win.
  • To get to know the objections of my (potential) customers. Phone calls have been my not-so-secret weapon since I started writing copy.
Thereâs NOTHING like talking to your prospects one- on-one to find out their pain points, their desires, their objections etc.

When I wrote my first ever sales letter in the Dating niche when I was 20 years old I only did one thing...

I called a couple guys. I asked them questions and I literally used what they told me, verbatim, for my copy. I didnât even know it was called âcopyâ at the time. I hadnât read a bunch of books or practiced hand copying sales letters yet.

I simply got to know my customer and then wrote based on what I learned.

To my complete and utter shock, the first sales letter I wrote actually made sales. All because of the phone calls.

Mini-lesson: One of the first books I read about copy is called âKick-Ass Copywriting Secrets of a Marketing Rebelâ by John Carlton. ( JC is a legend. I remember listening to his audiobook over and over again while I was training for a marathon. I revered him so highly I thought he was a myth. Now heâs a personal friend of mine. The world is weird. And it tends to reward you when you dedicate yourself to a craft.)
 
The reason I bring up that book is because John referred to a copywriter as a âSalesman in Print.â (At least thatâs what I remember.) I loved the idea because it meant I didnât have to be present to make a sale.

There was a really good piece of advice he had for salespeople:

Record your sales calls and get them transcribed. Add in the transitions and make it flow and...boom...you have a sales letter. Now you donât have to be present for every sale.

A few years ago I was writing a sales letter for skin care for older women.

Guess what I did.

I called my mum.

I said âwhy do you use skin care products? What are your issues with them? What have you already tried?â

She responded with a painfully beautiful sentence...

âI just want to look in the mirror and feel pretty again.â

Boom.

That literally became the first sentence of the sales letter.

You donât have to be brilliant or creative to hit home runs. Just let your customer write your copy for you.

Get on the phone with your prospects. Treat them like human beings. You may only be one phone call away from a brand new killer hook for your product.

When youâre talking to buyers itâs a little different.

IMPORTANT
Youâre not trying to get them off the fence. Youâre finding out what got them off the fence.
 
Here are some of the questions I like to ask buyers:

  • Why did you buy?
  • What was the moment you decided to buy?
  • When did you decide I was the person you wanted to learn from? Or we were the company you wanted to buy from?
  • Was their a specific piece of content or sales material that sold you?
  • What feeling did you want from this product?
  • What feelings did you have that drove you to buy the product?
  • What similar products have you bought in the past, if any? What did you like about them or dislike?
  • What result do/did you want to get from this product?
This is a great place to start.

Itâs also something you can do via email if youâre really resistant to the phone...or if you just want MORE data. I would recommend both.

I personally used simple âreply emailsâ to get data AND make sales at the same time. Hereâs a quick email you can use for your buyers to get great insights and data:

âHey, just a quick question for you...

Now letâs take this a step further. How do you use the information from these calls and emails to create a deep bond with your prospects?

Rule #9: Use the same language your prospects use.

You focus on the LANGUAGE of your prospects. Identify the words, phrases, lingo, etc that your target demographic uses.

  • If someone talks to me about tennis I can tell immediately if they actually understand the sport from just a couple of words.   • Think of a parent whoâs trying to fit in with their teenage kids. âI just want to look in the mirror and feel pretty again.â

âI just want to be able to play with my granddaughter without getting out of breath.â

RULE #10:

RULE #11:
SELL THEM WHAT THEY WANT
GIVE THEM WHAT THEY NEED

-Two Sentences To Live Or Die By As a Salesperson.-


This book simply wouldnât complete without a section on this topic.

IMPORTANT
The point of sales is NOT to solve a problem. Thatâs the purpose of the product or service youâre selling.
 
You are not selling someone what they NEED. Youâre selling them what they WANT.

Rule #11: Sell Them What They Want. Give Them What They Need.

This single concept can radically change your sales.

Let me give you some examples.

I have a world class copywriter friend who sold a product about how to get your ex back. The entire sales letter was designed around how to give them the exact result they wanted - getting back with their ex.
 
Yet the product itself was primarily designed to help people get over their ex. Yes, the strategies would help them get their ex back. But the main goal was actually to help them get over their ex so they could move on and enjoy their life again.
 
This is a huge distinction that I want to hammer home. If he wrote a sales letter that said âhow to get over your exâ it would hardly sell. Why? Because these people didnât want to get over their ex, they wanted them back!
 
The reality of human nature is that most people rarely know they need. But they know what they want.
 
Your purpose as a salesperson is to meet them where they are and sell them what they WANT. Then provide them with the actual solution they NEED.

This does NOT mean Iâm giving you permission to bait and switch people.

If someone says âI want a Ferrariâ and you sell them a Ferrari but give them a Honda cuz thatâs all they need...that makes you an asshole. This concept does not apply in that situation.

I used to teach dating bootcamps to men. In this situation it was incredibly important to sell them what they want and give them what they need.
 
You know what dudes who struggle with women want? They want the perfect pick up line. They want to know some âmagical phraseâ thatâs going to make women want them. They want to know what to say and how to approach women.
 
The reality is there is no perfect line. Thereâs no âgameâ thatâs going to truly help them attract who they want.
 
The harsh truth is that they have to change how they feel about themselves in order to change how other people feel about them. But that doesnât sell products. And if your product actually helps people then you have an ethical duty to do everything in your power to sell it - without lying of course.
 
You sell them the product about how to meet the woman of their dreams...and then you teach them how to actually like themselves so that women will like them too.

I really hope this is hitting home for you.

The type of people who REALLY need this concept are the people who say âmy product is so great people should want it. They NEED this. The world NEEDS this.â

Guess what? No one gives a fuck about your product. They care about themselves. You have to demonstrate how and why this product will give them what they want.

Itâs important to have a great product to build a long-term sustainable business. But it doesnât matter how life changing your product is if you canât sell it.

Do NOT get stuck in the trap of thinking people need your product. Or that people are going to magically decide that what you have is exactly what they want.

You are the bridge between where they are and where they want to be. It doesnât matter if youâre selling self-help or a vacuum.

People donât want self-help. They want to feel better or relieve their pain. People donât want a vacuum. They want clean carpets. Even deeper than that, they want their friends to be impressed by their clean carpets.

You have to tap into your prospects desires - not just their needs.



RULE #12:

So it wasnât about the physical event at all. It was the threat to my story.

My goal since then has been different than anything 15 year old Ian ever thought it would be:

To shed the stories. To surrender to each moment and realize that whether I achieve what I want to achieve or not, I am still enough.

To decide that the external world does not get to dictate my reality. That my reality is my own to create.

We do not have to be the by product of the world around us. The world around us can be the by product of our own free will.

In December of 2017 I started a book called The Surrender Experiment. Right around that time my girlfriend and I broke up. Or went on break. Whatever you want to call it. It wasnât the easiest thing.

It was the type of thing that tends to cripple people for weeks or months.

But I was reading this book and decided to dive in 100%. I decided to conduct my own Surrender Experiment. The results have been beyond anything I ever could have dreamed of...which youâll understand more as you read this.

So what is Surrender?

For most people it conjures up images of weakness. An army showing the white flag. Someone giving up. Arms raised in the air...full of defeat.

Or maybe...if youâre like me...it makes you think of the famous quote:

âNever Give Up. Never Surrender.â

That statement worked when applied to war. But it couldnât be further from the truth when it comes to life.

My motto has become:

âNever Give Up. Always Surrender.â So hereâs what Surrender means to me.

It means surrendering to reality. Surrendering to what IS. It means accepting the world and this moment for what it is. Not what you want it to be.

It means letting go of your personal preferences. Would you prefer it wasnât raining? Surrender. Would you prefer you and your girlfriend didnât break up? Surrender. Would you prefer you were born in a different time or to different parents? Surrender.

THIS MOMENT IS YOUR REALITY.

Iâm sorry to yell but you need to hear it. Thereâs NOTHING you can do to change that this moment is happening right now.

But there are things you can do to change future moments. And how you feel about past moments.

Surrender is not weakness. Itâs not saying âwell this is just how things are. Guess Iâll just give up.â

Itâs saying âthis is just how things are. If I want my future moments to change then thatâs up to ME.â

Itâs also saying âthis is my current reality. Iâm going to accept it and make peace with it.â

Itâs empowering.

Itâs a deep acceptance that you can only control what you can control. And you canât control much.

Itâs deciding that life has much bigger plans for you than you do. Itâs taking the first step when you canât see the staircase.

Itâs leaping into the abyss to see what it holds for you.

Itâs charging into the darkness to find the light.

Surrender is Trust. Itâs trusting that all things are exactly as theyâre meant to be.

Some people donât believe everything happens for a reason. I disagree with them.

I believe everything happened for a reason. Not necessarily because itâs true. (Who am I to decide whatâs true anyways?)

I believe it because it happened. And thereâs nothing I, or anyone else, can ever do to change the past. We can only change our perception of it.

In every moment we are faced with two choices. Resist. Or Surrender.

Resistance is the source of all pain, fear, anger, guilt, and shame. That doesnât mean itâs not ok to feel those emotions. You MUST feel those emotions. You are human. Itâs part of the experience. But you can let go of their hold on you. You can surrender.

You have a set of models youâve created about life. Beliefs of how things SHOULD be.

Any time the world doesnât match up with your belief of how things should be, youâre resisting. Youâre creating your own pain.

The world, in this moment, is exactly how it is.

The best explanation of enlightenment Iâve ever heard is also the simplest.

âThings pretty much are what they are. Dealing with the world on that level is enlightenment.â

You know who said that? Rory Miller. Prison guard for 25 years. Riot control leader. Guy who was in over 300 hand to hand encounters.

His job was to do violence.

Yet he lived in a state of deep surrender. (Iâve been lucky enough to spend time with him a few times and confirm that he lives in a way thatâs congruent with what he writes about.)

Surrender is not weakness. Surrender is understanding that violence exists. Accepting that itâs a REALITY of human existence. And itâs never going to go away.

So he could surrender to fact that violent people will hurt those who canât protect themselves. Or he could surrender to the reality of the existence of violence and train to deal with it.

Things arenât inherently good or bad. They just are.

Itâs the labels we put on things that make them good or bad.

Violence is not inherently bad. Itâs just the most emphatic way of saying NO. Dead people canât hurt people.

Most people are so attached to their labels that they create their own misery.

So what does any of this mean? Why am I telling you all of this in a book about persuasion? How can it affect your life?

The irony of my life is that I became obsessed with control. That obsession helped me to develop some amazing skills and change lives.

Yet our ability to actually control the world around us is limited.

Thatâs why I donât watch the news. Itâs why I donât concern myself with the opinions of people Iâll never meet - or change based on the opinions of people close to me.

I can control my attitude. I can control my actions. I can control the way I treat the people around me. Does that mean Iâm perfect? Hell no. I make mistakes. I slip up.

Thanks for going on this journey with me.

- A Recap of the Rules -


Weâve been on quite the little journey together.

Rule #1: Set clear boundaries.

This is the rule that I expect people to pay the least attention to.

Itâs easy to gloss over something that may not seem like it has that much to do with sales. But I really believe in this concept. Setting clear boundaries is my secret to working less and making more. Itâs why Iâve never overstepped my values or done anything shady to make a sale. Itâs an important first step towards building a life you enjoy.

Itâs not that hard to make a living. Itâs a lot harder to make a living and have a life. Boundaries are the key to having both.

Rule #2: Get the highest Average Order Value on every purchase.

Use every tool at your disposal to extract every dollar possible from each transaction...WITHOUT being a total scummy bastard.

Thereâs a right and wrong way to upsell stuff.

Wrong way -

âSo glad you bought my book about how to make money online. Now how about you join my pyramid scheme? All you have to do is recruit all your friends and family by bugging them about my these skinny teas that donât work.â

Right way -

Iâm so glad you bought my book about how to make money online. Do you mind if I show you the software I use that lets me build websites myself in just a few minutes instead of having to hire a designer and take months to do it.â

Itâs all about being congruent and helping serve your customer as well as you possibly can.

The more you think about what will serve them, the more youâll make.

One more note: The first upsell is the most important. Focus on this above all else. Test your highest price product in this slot. Test your continuity. Test it all.

But donât focus on your conversion rates. Focus on the actual dollar value itâs making for you.

Think about it this way.

If your first upsell is $100 and your second is $500, that first upsell has to convert 5x better than the second upsell for it to make sense. It may convert 10x better, you never know. But sometimes itâs best to throw that high priced item in that first slot to see what happens.

Focus on the first upsell above all else. Itâs a game changer.


Rule #3: Time and money are not related.

Society conditions us in so many different ways that we can never be aware of all of them. But this is one that you have to let go of. You have to rewire your brain to sever this connection that so many people are attached to.

IMPORTANT
The most common way to get paid is to trade time for money. Itâs easy. Itâs clean. Itâs measurable. Itâs convenient. But itâs complete and utter bollocks. (That means bullshit in American English.)
 
There are people whoâve made millions over the course of lifetimes. And people whoâve made billions in minutes. Time has no connection to money. Any connection it has is a construct weâve created as humans to make sense (and cents) of things. It helps us understand money, but it doesnât actually help us make more if it.
 
Time itself is a construct. Itâs convenient. Itâs not evil. Itâs not stupid. The concept of it will never go away. Yet you have to realize at your core that it is not real.

We all experience time in different ways. For one person, driving a car 150mph for 60 seconds may make time feel like it disappears all together. For someone else it may feel like the longest 60 seconds of their life.

Those things we do in life that make time seemingly disappear, tend to be the most enjoyable moments of our life. If you can find ways to immerse yourself in those type of moments in your work, youâll likely make a lot more money.

Think about it, when youâre in a state of deep flow, time ceases to exist. At least in the traditional sense. You arenât boxing your experience into neat little sections called minutes. You simply are. Youâre immersed.

The more energy you put into states of flow, the more youâll earn.

One last piece on the time/money connection.

Most people have a hard time accepting money for doing nothing. Or almost nothing.

For me, Iâve started to take a sense of deep joy from the things that pay me for doing almost nothing at all.

Iâll make an introduction to a couple of friends who end up making a bunch of money together and theyâll offer me money for that. I take it. I have no shame about it.

I donât need to work for money to come to me. Iâm not attached to that concept.

The idea that hard work and money are linked is just that - an idea. Itâs not a reality.

Money flows. Thatâs what it does. Thatâs its purpose. Itâs designed to move from one person to another. One business to another.

All you have to do is step inside that flow and grab whatâs in your path.


Rule #4: Youâre not charging enough.

Most people have a hard time raising their prices. Thatâs normal. Itâs ok. But you need to do your best to push yourself to raise your prices as often as you can if you offer a service. And when it comes to information products and physical products you need to TEST your prices. Whether itâs lower or higher, test.

One company I was working with tested just about everything you could think of on a sales page. Headlines, copy, design, upsells, etc...but they never tested the price on their front end product. It was $47. The reason they didnât test it? It was a pain with the software.
 
It doesnât matter how much of a pain it is, price should be one of the first things you test on an offer. With another client I took their $47 offer and changed it to $97. We assumed the conversion rate would go down but maybe itâd be worth it because of the extra money. Well, turns out the conversion rate stayed the same.
 
Same product, same copy, different price...and they doubled their revenue and multiplied profit dramatically.

Iâll say it again, test your prices. Test prices that make you uncomfortable.

Swing for the fences. Donât bunt.


Rule #5: Youâre Always Selling a Feeling.


ULTRA IMPORTANT
Most sales people think they are selling a thing, product, widget, service, opportunity, etc.
 
Despite popular belief, thatâs not the case. You are selling the feeling that the thing creates.
 
If this is the only thing you take from this book, itâll be worth it.
 
There are 8 core emotions.
  • Pain,
  • Fear,
  • Guilt,
  • Shame,
  • Anger,
  • Joy,
  • Love, and
  • Passion.
Walk through some steps before you work on your core sales message.
  • Identify the feelings your prospects are currently feeling. Are they angry, scared, ashamed? Tap into that.
  • Identify the feelings they want to feel.
  • Think about the stories you can tell to tap into those feelings at a deeper level.
  • Construct a bridge to take them from what theyâre feeling to what they want to feel.
  • Make them feel as many of the different emotions as you can throughout your sales message.
  • Build tension and desire, then allow them to release that tension by buying what youâre selling.
The more you can tap into your own feelings, the more you will sell.

You almost never hear someone say

âyou know what I liked most about that salesman? He didnât seem passionate at all about my problems or the product he was selling. He was a dispassionate robot with almost no ability to connect on a human level. I loved it.â

Your feelings and energy radiate out into the world and into your words, videos, phone calls, etc.

Allow yourself to feel more and youâll make more.

I know it can be weird to talk so much about feelings in a book about persuasion and selling but I swear itâs the secret weapon that will take you from good to great... or great to world class.


 
Rule #6: Do the Math.

I repeat this phrase so much to The Unit (thatâs my paid membership program) members that they must hate hearing it by now. But itâs THAT important.

People are lazy. Most of them donât like math. They arenât gonna do it in their heads so you have to do it for them.

Doing the math right is one of the best closing techniques you can ever employ.

One of the simplest ways I do this is with higher ticket items I sell.

For example, Iâll say

âSo you pay $10,000 once and add $25,000 a month to your bottom line. Is that worth it for you?â

They almost always say âYeah thatâs a no-brainer, letâs do it.â

I thought everyone did this until I found out how uncommon it is. People think itâs a given that people understand that. Theyâre wrong.

You can even go deeper with this...

âAn extra $25,000 a month is $300,000 a year in found money. If someone said âgive me $10,000 today and Iâll give you $300,000 at the end of the yearâ what would you say to that?â

Again, they say âyeah, letâs do it.â

Do the effiing math. (I feel like I should make one of those âeasyâ buttons like Staples did, but it should say âDo The Mathâ on it. Weâll see.)



Rule #7: Combine short term cash flow with long- term recurring revenue.

To me, this is the golden rule of business. Especially for direct response businesses or sales focused businesses. If you can find the fine line between short term cash flow and long-term revenue, you can scale to the moon. Or Mars. Maybe even further.

Itâs the magic equation. Do the math. What numbers do you need to hit? Know your numbers.

When you understand how much you can pay to acquire a customer, how long it takes to break even, and when they turn profitable, youâve got the formula for a big profitable monster of a business.

Donât fall into the trap of being a one or the other kind of business. Donât churn and burn or youâll constantly be looking for cash flow. Donât focus only on the long-term or youâll run out of cash.

Be like Goldilocks and find that spot in the middle that feels just right.


Rule #8: The first line of any sales message is the most important.

I live by this rule in everything I write. Itâs the one area of business where I will not allow an ounce of laziness from myself or anyone on my team. I wonât tolerate it from you either.

If youâre going to obsess over any part of a sales message, itâs the first part. (The second most important part is the offer/close.)

Look at the first sentence of this book:

I thought I was going to kill people for a living.

The purpose of that sentence is to get people to read the second sentence. In my opinion, itâs a strong first sentence. You want to know more. You want to know what the hell this guy is talking about. Thatâs not a common thing to think. It makes you curious. (At least I hope it did.)

Do NOT waste your first sentence on flaccid messaging.

Be disciplined with your opening lines.

Want to learn how to write amazing opening lines? Read the first line of bunch of old sales letters. Or you can do what I did, read and write down the first line of a bunch of books written by famous authors of thriller novels. Stuff by Lee Child, Vince Flynn, James Patterson, Tom Clancy, etc. Iâm not saying theyâre all amazing, but youâll notice that the first sentence, or at least the first paragraph pulls you in like a tractor beam. Rule #9: Use the same language your prospects use.

This one is pretty easy to understand. Learn the lingo of your target market. What phrases do they say? What phrases or words do they NOT say? What do they want to hear? What are the thoughts in their head?

Go deep. Become them.

Be like Christian Bale or Daniel Day Lewis. Theyâre method actors who become completely immersed in their roles...so much so that they put their health in danger. You shouldnât go that far, but you should get obsessed with your customer and how they speak.

You wouldnât send an email in Chinese to someone who only speaks English would you? Well, thatâs what it can feel like to a prospect when you donât use their language.


Rule #10: Identify your âclick moment.â

Every buyer has an exact moment when they decided to buy. Sometimes itâs multiple moments that linked up together to create their buying decision. A lot of the times the buyer may not even be aware of what pushed them over the edge.

Thatâs why itâs your job to reach out to your buyers and find out what made them buy.

Identify those moments where it âclickedâ for them that it was the product or service for them. Ask them the right questions and the selling is almost done for you.

Rule #11: Sell them what they want. Give them what they need.

It blows my mind how much trouble people have with this one. I think itâs a two-part struggle for people.

They either have some sort of moral/ethical dilemma with it, or they have trouble understanding it logically.

Letâs get rid of this moral/ethical dilemma first. If you have a product or service that truly helps people, it is your MORAL OBLIGATION to sell it to your prospects. You should sell as much of it to as many people as you can. Itâs your ethical duty to get the right people to buy it.

If you try to sell them what they need, you may be robbing your prospects of the opportunity to improve their lives.

When I was teaching dating to guys, I HAD to sell what they wanted. What they needed was to learn how to love themselves and increase their self-worth. But those guys didnât know that. They thought they needed pick up lines, weird routines, and new clothes. Itâs my job as the sales person (and product owner in this case) to get them to BUY into my world by tapping into what they wanted so that I could then give them what they needed.

Hereâs an exercise you can do:

IMPORTANT
Make two columns on a piece of paper. Label one Wants. Label the other Needs.
 
Write out everything they want in the wants column and everything they need in the needs column. Then focus on selling them what they want.
 
Itâs simple but effective.


Rule #12: Tell the stories that scare you the most.

People who are feeling a lot of emotions tend to buy a lot of stuff. The more you make them feel, the more likely they are to buy. Weâve already gone over this in length.

The shortcut to getting to people to tap into their emotions is to tap into your own. The best way to do that is to tell the stories that scare you the most.

The reason we focus on the stories that scare you is because they tend to be emotionally charged. They may be hard to write. They may be hard to relive. Or maybe youâre just scared to share them because youâre afraid of what people will think.

Hereâs the thing about worrying about what others will think of your story...

If itâs a bit embarrassing, or it was painful, or you think it makes you weird, thereâs an extremely high probability that someone else has experienced something similar. Or at least felt something similar.

My friend had a story about his bowel movements that he didnât want to share. He was ashamed of it. He didnât want to send that email out to his list. But one day he decided âfuck itâ letâs see what happens. Guess what? It was his highest- performing email ever. He got a shit ton (pun intended) of responses and sold a crap load (omg Ian stop it) of supplements.
 
As embarrassing as it felt for him, almost everyone has an embarrassing bowel movement story. Not only did people identify with it and take action to buy from him, they also built a deeper bond with him because they shared a common experience.

Embarrassing stories can be your ticket to lots of sales and long-term connection with your audience.

I learned the power of embarrassing stories when I started doing stand up comedy. (Yeah, Iâm a stand up comedian as well. Told you Iâve had an unusual life.)

Writing stand up material can be hard. It takes creativity, an understanding of human behavior, typically a lot of practice, and a whole lot of willingness to tolerate fear and embarrassment. Of all the crazy adrenaline activities and violence training Iâve done, stand up is still the scariest thing to do for me.

The reason Iâm telling you this is because I found a little shortcut. See, we all have embarrassing stories from our past. Some are so embarrassing that we thought weâd never tell a single soul about them. Yet if weâre willing to embrace that shame and share our story, we typically have something very emotional on our hands.

A lot of times the result of our embarrassment happens to be quite hilarious. Other times itâs deeply moving.

After my first stand up set I realized I could tell my embarrassing stories on stage and didnât require all the hard work of sitting down and writing jokes. The stories were inherently entertaining.

So sit down and think about some of your embarrassing stories. Which ones could help you sell your product? Which ones scare you? See if any of them can help


Rule #13: Donât let the stories you tell yourself define you.

Humans evolved telling stories. Itâs how we learn and connect. Itâs how we hand down important lessons to our children and future societies.

Stories keep humans alive. Before the written word it was the only way to pass on knowledge.

If we didnât have stories, weâd be dead.

Thatâs why weâre so in love with them.

Especially the ones we tell ourselves.

Whether weâre aware of it or not, there are stories we tell ourselves that donât serve us.

They may be things we learned from our childhood like:

âIâm stupid. Iâm always gonna be poor. Iâm useless. No one will ever love me.
 
I have to be perfect all the time. I have to be the best at everything. If I donât win then that makes me a loser.

Everything in life is a double edged sword. Nothing is an absolute. Nothing.

Nothing exists solely as a good or bad thing.

You grew up poor? Maybe youâll always be poor...or maybe itâs the best motivator to get rich.

You grew up rich? Maybe thatâll help you be successful... or maybe you never learned how to do stuff you donât want to do and youâll end up a lazy and on welfare.

Youâre naturally athletic? Maybe youâll be a pro athlete...or maybe you never learned how to practice because everything came easy so you end up wasting your talent.

Youâre not a natural salesperson? Maybe youâll struggle forever...or maybe thatâs the fuel you need to become world class.

I could go on and on, but I think you get the point.

You are the creator of your reality.

We all have a past. We all have strengths and weaknesses weâve developed because of it. Weâve all had ups and downs.

Itâs our unique path that makes us who we are. But that doesnât mean we are our past.

We can change the things we want to change.

We can rewrite our own stories and move through the world as the best version of ourselves.

Youâve read my story. Now go forth and write yours.
